title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024
text: The rapid advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AI) is reshaping the global job market, sparking debates about job displacement, salary disparities, and new career opportunities. As AI-driven automation permeates various industries, professionals must adapt to evolving skill demands. This report explores the growth and impact of AI vs.¬†Non-AI careers in 2024, providing insights into job security, salaries, industry trends, and emerging roles.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024
text: The rapid advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AI) is reshaping the global job market, sparking debates about job displacement, salary disparities, and new career opportunities. As AI-driven automation permeates various industries, professionals must adapt to evolving skill demands. This report explores the growth and impact of AI vs.¬†Non-AI careers in 2024, providing insights into job security, salaries, industry trends, and emerging roles.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024
text:
2 Research Rationale
AI‚Äôs influence on employment is twofold: it replaces some jobs while creating new opportunities. According to the World Economic Forum (2024), AI-driven automation will displace 85 million jobs by 2025 but simultaneously generate 97 million new positions. This shift necessitates a data-driven approach to understand:

How AI-powered careers compare to traditional job roles.
Which industries are experiencing AI-driven job growth vs.¬†job displacement.
What skillsets are most valuable in AI-powered and Non-AI professions.
How salary trends vary across AI and traditional careers.

By leveraging Lightcast data, GitHub collaboration, and Quarto publishing, this research aims to provide actionable career insights for job seekers in 2024.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024
text:
3 Literature Review

3.1 1. AI‚Äôs Impact on Employment
Smith ((2023)) found that industries such as finance, healthcare, and tech have seen an increase in AI-driven job roles, while sectors like retail, customer service, and manufacturing face higher automation risks.


3.2 2. Salary Trends in AI vs.¬†Traditional Careers
Johnson ((2024)) highlights that AI professionals (e.g., Machine Learning Engineers, Data Scientists) earn 30-50% more than their Non-AI counterparts (e.g., Mechanical Engineers, Accountants). The demand for AI-driven skills correlates with higher salaries and greater job security.


3.3 3. The Rise of AI-Driven Job Titles
Brown ((2024)) reports that AI advancements have led to new job roles, including Prompt Engineers, AI Ethics Officers, and Automation Specialists, which did not exist a decade ago.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024
text:
4 Preliminary Findings

4.1 1. AI vs.¬†Non-AI Job Growth (2024 Trends)

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024
text:
5 Career Strategy Recommendations
To adapt to AI-driven changes in the job market, professionals should:

Invest in AI & Data Science Skills üìä

Learn Python, Machine Learning, and AI-driven analytics.
Take courses in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Big Data.

Target High-Growth AI Industries üöÄ

Prioritize careers in finance, tech, and healthcare where AI adoption is rising.

Embrace AI-Powered Work Environments üí°

Stay ahead by using automation tools and AI-powered platforms in daily tasks.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Careers: Job Growth and Market Trends in 2024
text:
6 References


Brown, J. (2024): ‚ÄúThe future of automation in 2024,‚Äù Automation Journal,.


Johnson, L. (2024): ‚ÄúAI salaries and employment trends,‚Äù Economic Review,.


Smith, A. (2023): ‚ÄúArtificial intelligence and workforce disruption,‚Äù Tech Today,.


Quarto will automatically format citations from references.bib in Econometrica style.

title: Findings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth
text:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is reshaping industries, leading to both job displacement and job creation. According to the World Economic Forum (2024), AI will impact 85 million jobs but simultaneously create 97 million new ones (Forum (2024)).





Code
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

# Industry-wise job impact data
data = {
    "Industry": ["Tech & Data Science", "Finance", "Manufacturing", "Retail & Customer Service", "Healthcare", "Marketing & Advertising"],
    "Jobs Created": [500000, 300000, 250000, 200000, 400000, 150000],
    "Jobs Lost": [50000, 150000, 300000, 500000, 50000, 80000]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Create interactive bar chart
fig = px.bar(df, x="Industry", y=["Jobs Created", "Jobs Lost"], 
             title="AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth vs. Loss by Industry",
             barmode="group", labels={"value": "Number of Jobs", "variable": "Job Impact"})

fig.show()


        
        
        


                            
                                            


‚úÖ Finding: AI is not just eliminating jobs‚Äîit is reshaping job roles and requiring new skill sets (Online (2024)).

title: Findings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth
text:
2 2Ô∏è‚É£ AI vs.¬†Non-AI Career Salary Trends
As AI becomes more integrated into industries, AI-powered careers offer significantly higher salaries than traditional jobs (BizReport (2024)). Below is a comparison of AI vs.¬†Non-AI salaries in 2024.

2.1 üìà Interactive Table: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Job Salaries


Code
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import pandas as pd

# Salary comparison data
df_salary = pd.DataFrame({
    "Job Role": ["Machine Learning Engineer", "Data Scientist", "AI Risk Analyst (Finance)", "Software Developer", "Mechanical Engineer", "Customer Service Rep"],
    "AI-Powered Career?": ["‚úÖ Yes", "‚úÖ Yes", "‚úÖ Yes", "‚ùå No", "‚ùå No", "‚ùå No"],
    "Average Salary (2024)": ["$140,000", "$125,000", "$118,000", "$95,000", "$85,000", "$45,000"]
})

fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Table(
    header=dict(values=list(df_salary.columns),
                fill_color='paleturquoise',
                align='left'),
    cells=dict(values=[df_salary[col] for col in df_salary.columns],
               fill_color='lavender',
               align='left'))
])

fig.show()


                            
                                            


‚úÖ Finding: AI-powered careers command higher salaries than traditional roles, making AI skills essential for career advancement (Forbes (2024)).

title: Findings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth
section: 3 3Ô∏è‚É£ AI Job Automation Risks: Who Is at Risk?
text:
3 3Ô∏è‚É£ AI Job Automation Risks: Who Is at Risk?
AI is automating repetitive tasks across industries, putting millions of jobs at risk. Research from ScienceDirect (2024) shows that AI will impact several sectors over the next five years (ScienceDirect (2024)).







At-Risk Job Categories
Examples of Jobs AI is Replacing




Clerical Work
Data entry clerks, secretaries


Retail & Banking
Cashiers, bank tellers, call center agents


Manufacturing & Logistics
Assembly line workers, warehouse packers



‚úÖ Finding: The job displacement risk is highest for repetitive, rule-based tasks‚Äîbut AI-driven reskilling can mitigate this risk (Massachusetts (2024)).

title: Findings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth
text:
4 References


BizReport. (2024): ‚ÄúAI jobs paying the most in 2024: A salary report,‚Äù BizReport,.


Forbes. (2024): ‚ÄúFuture-proofing your career: The most in-demand AI skills,‚Äù Forbes,.


Forum, W. E. (2024): ‚ÄúAI & job market trends: Jobs lost and created by AI in 2024,‚Äù WEF Insights,.


Massachusetts, U. of. (2024): ‚ÄúHow to beat the ATS: Resume optimization in the AI era,‚Äù UMass Career Center,.

ScienceDirect. (2024): ‚ÄúAI-driven employment trends: A 2024 analysis,‚Äù Elsevier,.

title: Findings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Job Growth
text:
1 Introduction
The rapid advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has sparked an ongoing debate:
üöÄ Is AI replacing human workers, or is it creating more jobs than it destroys?
This study dives into the dual impact of AI‚Äîexploring both job displacement risks and emerging AI-driven career opportunities across industries.
With AI-driven automation on the rise, workers in every field must rethink their skill sets, adapt to new technologies, and find ways to future-proof their careers.



2 Why This Study Matters
The intersection of AI and employment is a crucial area of study in 2025, with direct implications for: ‚úÖ Employees ‚Äì How to adapt and upskill in an AI-powered world.
‚úÖ Employers ‚Äì Balancing automation with human workforce needs.
‚úÖ Governments ‚Äì Policies to manage job displacement.
‚úÖ Students & Job Seekers ‚Äì Identifying the most future-proof career paths.

2.0.1 üî• Key Questions We Address:

What jobs are most at risk of AI automation?

Which industries are growing due to AI?

Are AI-powered roles higher-paying than traditional jobs?

What should job seekers do to remain competitive?

These questions are not just theoretical‚Äîthey are critical for job seekers, policymakers, and businesses adapting to this shift.




3 AI‚Äôs Role in Job Disruption vs.¬†Job Creation
AI is not just replacing jobs‚Äîit is also creating new roles at an unprecedented pace.
The World Economic Forum (2024) predicts that 85 million jobs will be displaced, but 97 million new roles will emerge.

3.0.1 üö® Job Categories at Risk:
üíº Clerical Work ‚Üí Data entry clerks, secretaries
üè¶ Retail & Banking ‚Üí Cashiers, bank tellers
üè≠ Manufacturing ‚Üí Assembly line workers


3.0.2 üåü Fastest-Growing AI-Powered Careers:
üë®‚Äçüíª AI Engineers & Data Scientists ‚Üí Building AI models
üìà Algorithmic Traders ‚Üí AI-powered financial analysis
üé® AI-Powered Content Creators ‚Üí AI-driven marketing
The future workforce will need AI literacy, digital skills, and critical thinking to stay ahead of automation trends.




4 Overview of the Report
This study is divided into three core sections:

4.0.1 1Ô∏è‚É£ Findings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Jobs
üìå Analysis of job losses vs.¬†job creation across industries.
üìå How AI is transforming finance, healthcare, manufacturing, and retail.
üìå Salary trends for AI vs.¬†Non-AI careers.
‚û°Ô∏è Read the full findings here


4.0.2 2Ô∏è‚É£ Career Strategies ‚Äì How to Adapt to AI
üìå The most in-demand AI skills for job seekers.
üìå Industries with the highest AI job growth.
üìå Strategies to future-proof your career against AI disruption.
‚û°Ô∏è Explore career strategies here




5 Conclusion
AI is not just eliminating jobs‚Äîit is reshaping the job market.
This report provides data-driven insights into which jobs are at risk, which careers are thriving, and what skills are essential for long-term success.
üîé Final Takeaways:
‚úÖ AI will not make humans obsolete‚Äîit will redefine job roles.
‚úÖ Upskilling is the key to staying competitive.
‚úÖ AI is a tool for growth, not just disruption.
üöÄ Let‚Äôs explore how AI is transforming the job market!

title: Career Strategy
text:
With the rapid evolution of AI, professionals must stay ahead by adopting future-ready strategies. This section outlines key approaches to sustaining career growth in an AI-driven job market.





The rise of AI is transforming multiple industries, making it essential to develop skills in machine learning, AI ethics, and automation.
Enroll in certifications such as Google‚Äôs AI & ML program, IBM‚Äôs AI Engineering certification, or courses on Udacity and LinkedIn Learning.
Understanding AI-driven analytics and automation tools like Python, TensorFlow, and AutoML will provide a competitive edge in the job market (Forbes (2024)).





Companies increasingly integrate AI into remote and hybrid work models, requiring employees to be proficient in digital collaboration.
Mastering tools such as Slack, Zoom, and AI-powered project management systems like Asana or Trello is crucial.
Understanding AI-assisted work scheduling and workflow automation can help optimize productivity and efficiency in hybrid work settings (Forum (2024)).





More than 75% of companies use AI-powered ATS systems to scan resumes, meaning candidates must tailor their CVs to be AI-friendly.
Including industry-specific keywords, formatting resumes for machine readability, and avoiding excessive design elements will improve ranking in ATS systems.
Utilizing AI-driven resume analysis tools like Jobscan and Resume Worded can help refine applications before submission (Massachusetts (2024)).





While AI enhances efficiency, uniquely human skills such as critical thinking, emotional intelligence, and creativity remain indispensable.
Studies show that leadership, adaptability, and problem-solving abilities are among the top skills sought after by AI-driven organizations.
Professionals should engage in continuous learning through leadership workshops, problem-solving bootcamps, and mentorship programs to build these competencies (BizReport (2024)).





Expanding professional networks through AI-focused LinkedIn groups, online forums, and industry meetups is key to staying informed about job opportunities.
Participating in AI hackathons, conferences, and knowledge-sharing sessions like Google AI Summit or MIT AI Research Meetups can boost career prospects.
Research indicates that over 70% of job opportunities arise through networking rather than traditional job applications (Online (2024)).





As AI policies evolve, professionals must stay informed about data privacy laws, AI governance, and ethical considerations in automation.
Following organizations like the IEEE Standards Association and OpenAI Policy Institute will provide insights into regulatory changes and ethical AI implementation.
AI bias mitigation and compliance with international AI policies will be crucial for companies adopting AI solutions (ScienceDirect (2024)).













Factor
AI-Driven Careers
Traditional Careers




Job Growth
High (Projected 97M new jobs)
Moderate growth


Skill Requirement
AI, ML, Data Science
Industry-Specific Skills


Salary Trends
Higher Earning Potential
Stable Salaries


Job Security
Requires Continuous Learning
More Stability


Work Environment
Hybrid & Remote Work
On-Site Preferred


Key Industries
Tech, Finance, Healthcare
Manufacturing, Retail






AI is not just a disruptor but also a creator of new job opportunities. The World Economic Forum predicts that AI will generate 97 million new jobs globally by 2025, particularly in AI ethics, cybersecurity, and AI-powered customer experience roles. To remain relevant, professionals must:

Pursue AI-related certifications and continuous education.
Build a strong portfolio showcasing AI and data-driven projects.
Develop a flexible mindset, embracing AI as a tool rather than a threat.

title: Career Strategy
text:
The rise of AI is transforming multiple industries, making it essential to develop skills in machine learning, AI ethics, and automation.
Enroll in certifications such as Google‚Äôs AI & ML program, IBM‚Äôs AI Engineering certification, or courses on Udacity and LinkedIn Learning.
Understanding AI-driven analytics and automation tools like Python, TensorFlow, and AutoML will provide a competitive edge in the job market (Forbes (2024)).





Companies increasingly integrate AI into remote and hybrid work models, requiring employees to be proficient in digital collaboration.
Mastering tools such as Slack, Zoom, and AI-powered project management systems like Asana or Trello is crucial.
Understanding AI-assisted work scheduling and workflow automation can help optimize productivity and efficiency in hybrid work settings (Forum (2024)).





More than 75% of companies use AI-powered ATS systems to scan resumes, meaning candidates must tailor their CVs to be AI-friendly.
Including industry-specific keywords, formatting resumes for machine readability, and avoiding excessive design elements will improve ranking in ATS systems.
Utilizing AI-driven resume analysis tools like Jobscan and Resume Worded can help refine applications before submission (Massachusetts (2024)).





While AI enhances efficiency, uniquely human skills such as critical thinking, emotional intelligence, and creativity remain indispensable.
Studies show that leadership, adaptability, and problem-solving abilities are among the top skills sought after by AI-driven organizations.
Professionals should engage in continuous learning through leadership workshops, problem-solving bootcamps, and mentorship programs to build these competencies (BizReport (2024)).





Expanding professional networks through AI-focused LinkedIn groups, online forums, and industry meetups is key to staying informed about job opportunities.
Participating in AI hackathons, conferences, and knowledge-sharing sessions like Google AI Summit or MIT AI Research Meetups can boost career prospects.
Research indicates that over 70% of job opportunities arise through networking rather than traditional job applications (Online (2024)).





As AI policies evolve, professionals must stay informed about data privacy laws, AI governance, and ethical considerations in automation.
Following organizations like the IEEE Standards Association and OpenAI Policy Institute will provide insights into regulatory changes and ethical AI implementation.
AI bias mitigation and compliance with international AI policies will be crucial for companies adopting AI solutions (ScienceDirect (2024)).

title: Career Strategy
text:
AI is not just a disruptor but also a creator of new job opportunities. The World Economic Forum predicts that AI will generate 97 million new jobs globally by 2025, particularly in AI ethics, cybersecurity, and AI-powered customer experience roles. To remain relevant, professionals must:

title: About This Project
text:
In a world where AI is stealing jobs and creating new ones, we (a bunch of stressed-out graduate students) decided to investigate:
Is AI actually replacing humans, or is it just another industry hype?


Because job hunting in 2024 feels like a game where AI gets all the power-ups while we, the humble human job seekers, are stuck grinding for XP.
We wanted to analyze: ‚úÖ AI vs.¬†Non-AI job growth ‚Äì Are humans still relevant?
‚úÖ Salary trends ‚Äì Does AI work pay more, or are robots underpaid?
‚úÖ Resume hacks ‚Äì Beating AI at its own game (ATS filtering).



We‚Äôre just a team of data-driven detectives, using Python, AI models, and analytics to crack the job market code.
Meet the crew:
- Vidhi A. Sharma ‚Äì AI optimist (or just hopeful AI won‚Äôt take all jobs).
- Soham Deshkhaire ‚Äì Machine Learning enthusiast trying to outsmart AI.
- Nhan (Johnny) Huynh ‚Äì The coding wizard making all the magic happen.
üöÄ Our Goal: To create a research-driven career strategy so humans (us) can still land jobs in 2024!

3 3Ô∏è‚É£ AI Job Automation Risks: Who Is at Risk?
AI is automating repetitive tasks across industries, putting millions of jobs at risk. Research from ScienceDirect (2024) shows that AI will impact several sectors over the next five years (ScienceDirect (2024)).







At-Risk Job Categories
Examples of Jobs AI is Replacing




Clerical Work
Data entry clerks, secretaries


Retail & Banking
Cashiers, bank tellers, call center agents


Manufacturing & Logistics
Assembly line workers, warehouse packers



‚úÖ Finding: The job displacement risk is highest for repetitive, rule-based tasks‚Äîbut AI-driven reskilling can mitigate this risk (Massachusetts (2024)).

title: Career Strategy
text:
With the rapid evolution of AI, professionals must stay ahead by adopting future-ready strategies. This section outlines key approaches to sustaining career growth in an AI-driven job market.





The rise of AI is transforming multiple industries, making it essential to develop skills in machine learning, AI ethics, and automation.
Enroll in certifications such as Google‚Äôs AI & ML program, IBM‚Äôs AI Engineering certification, or courses on Udacity and LinkedIn Learning.
Understanding AI-driven analytics and automation tools like Python, TensorFlow, and AutoML will provide a competitive edge in the job market (Forbes (2024)).





Companies increasingly integrate AI into remote and hybrid work models, requiring employees to be proficient in digital collaboration.
Mastering tools such as Slack, Zoom, and AI-powered project management systems like Asana or Trello is crucial.
Understanding AI-assisted work scheduling and workflow automation can help optimize productivity and efficiency in hybrid work settings (Forum (2024)).





More than 75% of companies use AI-powered ATS systems to scan resumes, meaning candidates must tailor their CVs to be AI-friendly.
Including industry-specific keywords, formatting resumes for machine readability, and avoiding excessive design elements will improve ranking in ATS systems.
Utilizing AI-driven resume analysis tools like Jobscan and Resume Worded can help refine applications before submission (Massachusetts (2024)).





While AI enhances efficiency, uniquely human skills such as critical thinking, emotional intelligence, and creativity remain indispensable.
Studies show that leadership, adaptability, and problem-solving abilities are among the top skills sought after by AI-driven organizations.
Professionals should engage in continuous learning through leadership workshops, problem-solving bootcamps, and mentorship programs to build these competencies (BizReport (2024)).





Expanding professional networks through AI-focused LinkedIn groups, online forums, and industry meetups is key to staying informed about job opportunities.
Participating in AI hackathons, conferences, and knowledge-sharing sessions like Google AI Summit or MIT AI Research Meetups can boost career prospects.
Research indicates that over 70% of job opportunities arise through networking rather than traditional job applications (Online (2024)).





As AI policies evolve, professionals must stay informed about data privacy laws, AI governance, and ethical considerations in automation.
Following organizations like the IEEE Standards Association and OpenAI Policy Institute will provide insights into regulatory changes and ethical AI implementation.
AI bias mitigation and compliance with international AI policies will be crucial for companies adopting AI solutions (ScienceDirect (2024)).

AI-Driven Careers
Traditional Careers

AI is not just a disruptor but also a creator of new job opportunities. The World Economic Forum predicts that AI will generate 97 million new jobs globally by 2025, particularly in AI ethics, cybersecurity, and AI-powered customer experience roles. To remain relevant, professionals must:

Pursue AI-related certifications and continuous education.
Build a strong portfolio showcasing AI and data-driven projects.
Develop a flexible mindset, embracing AI as a tool rather than a threat.

title: AI vs.¬†Non-AI Job Growth: Is AI Taking Over or Creating More Jobs?
text:
1 Introduction
The rapid advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has sparked an ongoing debate:
üöÄ Is AI replacing human workers, or is it creating more jobs than it destroys?
This study dives into the dual impact of AI‚Äîexploring both job displacement risks and emerging AI-driven career opportunities across industries.
With AI-driven automation on the rise, workers in every field must rethink their skill sets, adapt to new technologies, and find ways to future-proof their careers.



2 Why This Study Matters
The intersection of AI and employment is a crucial area of study in 2025, with direct implications for: ‚úÖ Employees ‚Äì How to adapt and upskill in an AI-powered world.
‚úÖ Employers ‚Äì Balancing automation with human workforce needs.
‚úÖ Governments ‚Äì Policies to manage job displacement.
‚úÖ Students & Job Seekers ‚Äì Identifying the most future-proof career paths.

2.0.1 üî• Key Questions We Address:

What jobs are most at risk of AI automation?

Which industries are growing due to AI?

Are AI-powered roles higher-paying than traditional jobs?

What should job seekers do to remain competitive?

These questions are not just theoretical‚Äîthey are critical for job seekers, policymakers, and businesses adapting to this shift.




3 AI‚Äôs Role in Job Disruption vs.¬†Job Creation
AI is not just replacing jobs‚Äîit is also creating new roles at an unprecedented pace.
The World Economic Forum (2024) predicts that 85 million jobs will be displaced, but 97 million new roles will emerge.

3.0.1 üö® Job Categories at Risk:
üíº Clerical Work ‚Üí Data entry clerks, secretaries
üè¶ Retail & Banking ‚Üí Cashiers, bank tellers
üè≠ Manufacturing ‚Üí Assembly line workers


3.0.2 üåü Fastest-Growing AI-Powered Careers:
üë®‚Äçüíª AI Engineers & Data Scientists ‚Üí Building AI models
üìà Algorithmic Traders ‚Üí AI-powered financial analysis
üé® AI-Powered Content Creators ‚Üí AI-driven marketing
The future workforce will need AI literacy, digital skills, and critical thinking to stay ahead of automation trends.




4 Overview of the Report
This study is divided into three core sections:

4.0.1 1Ô∏è‚É£ Findings ‚Äì AI‚Äôs Impact on Jobs
üìå Analysis of job losses vs.¬†job creation across industries.
üìå How AI is transforming finance, healthcare, manufacturing, and retail.
üìå Salary trends for AI vs.¬†Non-AI careers.
‚û°Ô∏è Read the full findings here


4.0.2 2Ô∏è‚É£ Career Strategies ‚Äì How to Adapt to AI
üìå The most in-demand AI skills for job seekers.
üìå Industries with the highest AI job growth.
üìå Strategies to future-proof your career against AI disruption.
‚û°Ô∏è Explore career strategies here




5 Conclusion
AI is not just eliminating jobs‚Äîit is reshaping the job market.
This report provides data-driven insights into which jobs are at risk, which careers are thriving, and what skills are essential for long-term success.
üîé Final Takeaways:
‚úÖ AI will not make humans obsolete‚Äîit will redefine job roles.
‚úÖ Upskilling is the key to staying competitive.
‚úÖ AI is a tool for growth, not just disruption.
üöÄ Let‚Äôs explore how AI is transforming the job market!
